facts.text: Writ Petitions Nos. 90 to 112 of 1962 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petitions Nos. 90 to 11 2 of 1962. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J. on September 28, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. September 28. The judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-Since 1958 the Stale of Mysore has been endeavouring to make a special provision

facts.text: State of Mysore passed order on July 31, 1962 under Article 15(4) reserving seats for backward classes.

anchor.surface_text: the present petitions filed by the respective petitioners under Art. 32 dispute the validity of the last order passed by the State of Mysore on the July 31, 1962, under Art. 15  4 .

facts.text: Six petitioners applied for admission to Pre-professional Class in Medicine in Medical Colleges affiliated to Mysore or Karnatak University.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the twenty-three petitioners, six had applied for admission to the Pre-professional Class in Medicine in the Medical Colleges affiliated either to the Mysore University or to the Karnatak University,

facts.text: Seventeen petitioners applied for admission to First Year of 5 Year integrated course leading to B.E. in University of Mysore.

anchor.surface_text: and seventeen had applied for admission to the First Year of the 5 Year integrated companyrse leading to the Degree of B. E. in the University of Mysore.

facts.text: Due to impugned order reservation, petitioners denied admission despite entitlement but for reservation; lower mark students admitted instead.

anchor.surface_text: According to the petitioners, but for the reservation made by the impugned order, they would have been entitled to the admission in the respective companyleges for which they had applied.

facts.text: Impugned order provides 68% reservation: 50% for Other Backward Classes (28% Backward Classes, 22% More Backward Classes), 15% Scheduled Castes, 3% Scheduled Tribes.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of this order is that it has fixed 50 as the quota for the reservation of seats for Other Backward Classes 28 out of this is reserved for Backward Classes so-called and 22 for More Backward Classes.

facts.text: State order on July 26, 1958 reserved 75% seats for all communities except Brahmins, 15% Scheduled Castes, 3% Scheduled Tribes.

anchor.surface_text: On the 26th,July 1958, the State issued an order that all the companymunities, excepting the Brahmin companymunity, fell within the definition of educationally and socially Backward Classes

facts.text: 1958 order quashed by Mysore High Court after State conceded drafting error.

anchor.surface_text: The order issued by the State on the 26th July, 1958, was challenged before the Mysore High Court and it appears that the State companyceded before the High Court that there was a drafting error

facts.text: State passed orders on May 14, 1959 and July 22, 1959 classifying communities except Brahmins, Baniyas, Kayasths, Muslims, Christians, Jains as backward, reserving 65%.

anchor.surface_text: In 1959, two separate orders were passed by the State on the 14th May and 22nd July respectively. By the first order, all companymunities, excepting Brahmins, Baniyas and Kayasts among the Hindus and Muslims,

facts.text: 1959 orders quashed by Mysore High Court in Ramakrishna Singh v. State of Mysore.

anchor.surface_text: These orders were challenged before the Mysore High Court in the case of Ramakrishna Singh Ram Singh State of Mysore 1 . The High Court upheld the pleas raised by the petitioners

facts.text: State appointed Mysore Backward Classes Committee (Nagan Gowda Committee).

anchor.surface_text: The State then appointed a Committee called the Mysore Backward Classes Committee with Dr. R. Nagan Gowda as its Chairman,

facts.text: Order on June 9, 1960 based on interim report: 60% merit pool, 40% reservation (22% Backward, 15% SC, 3% ST).

anchor.surface_text: the State passed an order on the 9th June, 1960 regulating admissions for that year into the professional and technical companyleges. Broadly stated, the effect of this order was that 60 of the seats

facts.text: 1960 order challenged and partially invalidated by Mysore High Court in S.A. Partha v. State of Mysore.

anchor.surface_text: This order was also challenged before the Mysore High Court in S. A. Partha v. The State of Mysore 1 . It appears that, on the whole, the High Court did number feel satisfied

facts.text: Nagan Gowda Committee final report in 1961 led to order on July 10, 1961 with 48% total reservation (30% Backward Classes).

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the Nagan Gowda Committee made its report in 1961 and in the light of the said report and the recommendations made therein, the State proceeded to make an order under Art. 15  4  on July 10, 1961.

facts.text: Impugned order supersedes all previous orders under Art. 15(4).

anchor.surface_text: On July 31, 1962, the State passed the impugned order which supersedes all previous orders made by the State under Art. 15 4

facts.text: Petitioners claim impugned order basis for backward classes is unintelligible, irrational, inconsistent with Art. 15(4).

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners case is that the impugned order which has been passed under Art. 15  4  is number valid because the basis adopted by the order in specifying and enumerating the socially and educationally backward classes

facts.text: Petitioners claim extent of reservation (68%) unreasonable, extravagant, fraud on Art. 15(4).

anchor.surface_text: It is also urged by them that the extent of reservation prescribed by the said order is so unreasonable and extravagant that the order, in law, is number justified by Art. 15  4

facts.text: State denies allegations; claims classification rational, reservation justified by Art. 15(4), not fraud.

anchor.surface_text: These allegations are denied by the State and it is urged on its behalf that the classification made is both rational and intelligible and the reservation prescribed by the order is fully justified by Art. 15  4 .

facts.text: Backward Classes Commission appointed by President on January 29, 1953 under Art. 340(1), report March 30, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: On January 29, 1953, the President appointed the Backward Classes Commission by virtue of the power companyferred on him under Art. 340  1  of the Constitution. This Commission made its report on March 30, 1955.

facts.text: Nagan Gowda Committee classified Backward Classes on basis of castes and communities.

anchor.surface_text: the Nagan Gowda Committee appointed by the State was inclined to treat the caste as almost the sole basis in determining the question about the social backwardness of any companymunity.

facts.text: Court holds classification of backward classes based solely on caste impermissible under Art. 15(4).

anchor.surface_text: the classification of the socially backward classes of citizens made by the State proceeds on the only companysideration of their castes without regard to the other factors which are undoubtedly relevant.

facts.text: Court holds 68% reservation inconsistent with Art. 15(4), should be less than 50%.

anchor.surface_text: we are satisfied that the reservation of 68 directed by the impugned order is plainly inconsistent with Art. 15  4 .

facts.text: Impugned order held fraud on Constitutional power under Art. 15(4).

anchor.surface_text: the impugned order is a fraud on the Constitutional power companyferred on the State by Art. 15  4 .

facts.text: Writ petitions allowed; respondents restrained from implementing impugned order.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we allow the writ petitions and direct, that an appropriate writ or order or direction should, be issued restraining the three respondents from giving effect to the impugned order

holdings.text: Art. 15(4) must be read as a proviso or exception to Arts. 15(1) and 29(2); if justified under Art. 15(4), order valid despite apparent violation of 15(1)/29(2).

anchor.surface_text: Thus, there is no doubt that Art. 15 4  has to be read as a proviso or an exception to Articles 15 1  and 29 2 . In other words, if the impugned order is justified by the provisions of Art. 15 4 , its validity cannot be impeached

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual and harmonious construction; added by 1st Amendment post-Champakam Dorairajan to align with Art.16(4).

holdings.text: State competent to make special provision under Art. 15(4) without prior appointment of Commission under Art. 340(1) or laying report before Parliament under Art. 340(3).

anchor.surface_text: The first argument which has been urged by Mr. Iyyangar on behalf of the petitioners is that it is not competent to the State to make an order under Art. 15 4  unless a Commission has been appointed under Art. 340 1  and a copy of the report of the said Commission is laid before the House of Parliament under Art. 340 3 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.340 recommendations for Union/State action, not condition precedent; President lays report but States act independently.

holdings.text: Special provision under Art. 15(4) can be made by executive order, not necessarily by legislation.

anchor.surface_text: Under Art. 12, the State includes the Government and the Legislature of each of the States, and so, it would be unreasonable to suggest that the State must necessarily mean the Legislature and not the Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.12 defines State to include executive; contrast with Arts.16(3),(5),341(2),342(2) specifying 'law'.

holdings.text: Classification of backward classes solely on basis of caste, without other relevant factors, is impermissible under Art. 15(4).

anchor.surface_text: the classification of the socially backward classes of citizens made by the State proceeds on the only consideration of their castes without regard to the other factors which are undoubtedly relevant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Caste relevant but not sole/dominant test; must consider poverty, occupation, habitation; perpetuates caste otherwise; inapplicable to non-Hindus.

holdings.text: Impugned order determines social backwardness in manner not permissible under Art. 15(4), introducing fatal infirmity.

anchor.surface_text: If that be so, the social backwardness of the communities to whom the impugned order applies has been determined in a manner which is not permissible under Art. 15 4  and that itself would introduce an infirmity which is fatal to the validity of the said classification.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Nagan Gowda Committee and orders treat caste as sole/practicable basis; no evidence of other factors applied.

holdings.text: State not justified in treating communities with student population average near or just below State average as educationally backward.

anchor.surface_text: The next question to consider is in regard to the educational backwardness of the classes of citizens.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Must be well/substantially below State average (e.g. Lingayats at 7.1 vs 6.9/7); test itself questionable but as applied invalid.

holdings.text: Sub-classification between Backward Classes and More Backward Classes not justified under Art. 15(4).

anchor.surface_text: In this connection, it is necessary to add that the sub- classification made by the order- between Backward Classes and More Backward Classes does not appear to be justified under Art. 15 4 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.15(4) for really backward classes, not all less advanced vs most advanced; results in 90% population as backward.

holdings.text: Reservation of 68% seats plainly inconsistent with Art. 15(4); special provision must be reasonable and generally less than 50%.

anchor.surface_text: we are satisfied that the reservation of 68 directed by the impugned order is plainly inconsistent with Art. 15 4 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Balance weaker sections with merit/national interest; analogy to Art.16(4); subverts object if excessive; State earlier rejected 68%.

holdings.text: Impugned order is a fraud on the Constitutional power conferred by Art. 15(4).

anchor.surface_text: the impugned order is a fraud on the Constitutional power conferred on the State by Art. 15 4 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Latent transgression via invalid caste classification and excessive reservation; substance over form.

holdings.text: Doctrine of severability inapplicable; cannot sever invalid portions of impugned order.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Advocate-General has made an earnest and strong plea before us that we should not strike down the order, but should strike down only such portions of the order which appear to us to be unconstitutional on the doctrine of severability.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cannot recategorise classes or fix percentage; whole order invalid.

holdings.text: Writ petitions allowed; respondents restrained from implementing impugned order.

anchor.surface_text: These orders were challenged before the Mysore High Court in the case of Ramakrishna Singh Ram Singh State of Mysore 1 . The High Court upheld the pleas raised by the petitioners and quashed the impugned  1  A.I.R. 1960 Mysore 338. A.I.R. 1960 Mysore 338. orders.

precedents.case_name: Ramakrishna Singh v. State of Mysore
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court quashed government orders classifying communities other than Brahmins, Baniyas, Kayasths, Muslims, Christians and Jains as socially and educationally backward classes and reserving 65% seats for them

anchor.surface_text: This order was also challenged before the Mysore High Court in S. A. Partha v. The State of Mysore 1 . It appears that, on the whole, the High Court did number feel satisfied that the scheme of the special provision made by the impugned order was invalid, but it thought that the allotment of seats under the provisions of the said order in favour of the other Backward Classes in excess of 22 reserved for them otherwise than by open competition amounted to an unreasonable restraint on the fundamental right of other citizens and, therefore, was invalid. Having reached this decision, the High Court indi- cated the manner in which the reservation in favour of the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes and other Backward Classes should be worked out so as to A.I.R. 1961 Mysore 220, avoid a successful challenge under Arts. 15  1  and 29  2 .

precedents.case_name: S. A. Partha v. State of Mysore
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court invalidated excess reservation for other Backward Classes beyond open competition but indicated manner to work out reservations validly

anchor.surface_text: It will be recalled that in the case of The State of v. Srimathi Champakam Dorairajan 1  the validity of the Government order issued by the Madras Government fixing certain proportions in which students seeking for admissions to the Engineering and Medical Colleges in the State should be admitted, was challenged. The said Government Order was on the face of it a communal order fixing the admissions in the Stated proportion by reference to the communities of. the candidates. This order was struck down by the Madras High Court and the decision of the Madras High Court was confirmed by this Court in appeal, on the ground that the fundamental rights guaranteed by Articles 15 1  and 29 2  were number controlled by any exception, and that since there was numberprovision under Art. 15 corresponding to Art. 16 4 , the impugned order could number be sustained. It was directly as a result of this decision that Art. 15 was amended and Art. 15 4  was added. Thus, there is numberdoubt that Art. 15 4  has to be read as a proviso or an exception to Articles 15 1  and 29 2 .

precedents.case_name: State of Madras v. Champakam Dorairajan
precedents.cited_proposition: Communal reservation order for admissions violated Articles 15(1) and 29(2) as there was no provision like Article 16(4) in Article 15, leading to the addition of Article 15(4)
precedents.cited_holding: Government order fixing admissions by community proportions struck down

anchor.surface_text: Whilst we are dealing with this question, it would be relevant to add that the provisions of Art. 15 4  are similar to those of Art. 16 4  which fell to be considered in the case of The General Manager, Southern Railway v. Rangoon 1 . In that case, the majority decision of this Court held that the power of reservation which is conferred on the State under Art. 16 4  can be exercised by the State, in a proper case number only by providing for reservation of appointments, but also by providing for reservation of selection posts. This conclusion was reached on the basis that it served to give effect to the intention of the Constitution-makers to make adequate safeguards for the advancement of Backward Classes and to secure their adequate representation in the Services.

precedents.case_name: General Manager, Southern Railway v. Rangachari
precedents.cited_proposition: Article 16(4) permits reservation not only of appointments but also of selection posts to advance backward classes
precedents.cited_holding: Reservation under Article 16(4) extends to selection posts
